Lost [[2009â10 NFL playoffs|Conference Championship]] ([[New Orleans Saints|Saints]]) 31â28 (OT) | pro bowlers = {{Collapsible list |title = 10 |1 = QB [[Brett Favre]] (bench; injured) |2 = RB [[Adrian Peterson]] |3 = WR [[Sidney Rice]] (bench) |4 = OT [[Bryant McKinnie]] (cut) |5 = G [[Steve Hutchinson (American football)|Steve Hutchinson]] |6 = DE [[Jared Allen]] |7 = DT [[Kevin Williams (defensive tackle)|Kevin Williams]] |8 = CB [[Antoine Winfield]] (injured) |9 = KR [[Percy Harvin]] (injured) |10 = ST [[Heath Farwell]] }} | AP All-pros = {{Collapsible list |title = 4 |1 = RB Adrian Peterson ''(1st team)'' |2 = G Steve Hutchinson ''(1st team)'' |3 = DE Jared Allen ''(1st team)'' |4 = DT Kevin Williams ''(1st team)'' }} | uniform = File:NFCN-Uniform-MIN.PNG }} The '''2009 Minnesota Vikings season''' was the [[Minnesota Vikings|franchise]]'s 49th season in the [[National Football League|NFL]]. The Vikings improved upon their 10â6 record and defended their NFC North title from [[2008 Minnesota Vikings season|2008]]; it was the first time that they had retained a divisional title since they won six [[NFC Central]] titles in a row between [[1973 Minnesota Vikings season|1973]] and [[1978 Minnesota Vikings season|1978]]. They beat the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in the NFC Divisional Playoff, but lost the NFC Championship Game in overtime to the [[New Orleans Saints]], missing out on what would have been their first Super Bowl since [[Super Bowl XI|1976]]. It was their fourth season under the direction of head coach [[Brad Childress]], and they played their home games at [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome|Mall of America Field at the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]]. The Vikings had ten Pro Bowlers and four All-Pros on their roster, both league-highs for the season. {{TOClimit|3}} ==Offseason== ===Player and personnel moves=== [[Quarterback]] [[Brett Favre]] announced that he would not sign with the Minnesota Vikings on July 28, 2009, after much speculation that he would. However, on August 18, Favre signed a 2-year contract worth $25 million with the Vikings. ====Releases and injuries==== On February 18, the team released [[running back]] [[Maurice Hicks]].http://www.twincities.com/ci_11735620 On February 27, the team released [[quarterback]] [[Gus Frerotte]].http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_11803718 On March 3, the team released [[linebacker]] [[Vinny Ciurciu]].http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_11825908 On March 4, free agent center [[Matt Birk]] left the Vikings to join the [[Baltimore Ravens]].http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_11835768 On March 18, free agent safety [[Darren Sharper]] left the Vikings to join the [[New Orleans Saints]].http://www.nfl.com/teams/transactions?team=NO ====Signings and extensions==== [[File:2009-0805-SRosenfels.jpg|thumb|170px|[[Sage Rosenfels]]]] On February 24, the team re-signed [[cornerback]] [[Charles Gordon (American football)|Charles Gordon]] to a 1-year $1 million contract.http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/40260542.html On February 26, the team re-signed [[defensive end]] [[Jayme Mitchell]] to a 2-year deal.http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/40395427.html On February 27, the Vikings traded a 2009 4th round pick to the [[Houston Texans]] for quarterback [[Sage Rosenfels]]. They then signed Rosenfels to a 2-year $9 million contract extension that will run through 2011.http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/40421597.html On February 27, the team re-signed [[tight end]] [[Jim Kleinsasser]] to a 3-year $9 million contract.http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/40457097.html On March 6, the team re-signed linebacker [[Heath Farwell]] to a 3-year $7.75 million contract.http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_11852183 On March 9, the team re-signed cornerback [[Benny Sapp]] to a 1-year contract.{{cite web |title=Access Vikings: » Blog Archive » Sapp to return |url=http://blogs.startribune.com/vikingsblog/?p=2608 |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5igyNvVXN|archivedate=31 July 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=11 March 2009 }} On March 11, the team re-signed defensive tackle [[Jimmy Kennedy (American football)|Jimmy Kennedy]] to a 1-year contract.http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_11888108?nclick_check=1 On March 19, the Vikings signed cornerback [[Karl Paymah]] and wide receiver [[Glenn Holt]].http://www.nfl.com/teams/minnesotavikings/transactions?team=MIN On March 21, cornerback [[Cedric Griffin]] signed a 3-year contract extension. On March 27, the team matched the Bengals' offer sheet for RFA fullback [[Naufahu Tahi]]. On March 31, the team re-signed defensive end [[Otis Grigsby]] to a 1-year deal.http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_12039582 On April 6, the team re-signed defensive tackle [[Fred Evans (American football)|Fred Evans]] to a 1-year deal. On July 24, [[Antoine Winfield]] and the Vikings agreed on a 5-year extension through the 2013 season.http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4351332 On August 18, after months of negotiations, the team signed formerly retired quarterback [[Brett Favre]]. ===2009 NFL Draft=== The Vikings had five selections in the [[2009 NFL Draft]]; they had traded their fourth-round selection to the [[Houston Texans]] for quarterback [[Sage Rosenfels]] and, back in 2007, they had traded their sixth-round selection to the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] in exchange for quarterback [[Kelly Holcomb]]. In 2008, they received an extra 2009 seventh-round selection from the [[Washington Redskins]] for defensive end [[Erasmus James]], but they used that extra pick to move from spot #158 to #150 in the fifth round. The Vikings' top two selections, WR [[Percy Harvin]] and OT [[Phil Loadholt]], both soon became 1st string players, while [[Jasper Brinkley]] finished the season as the team's starting MLB after [[E.J. Henderson]] suffered a broken leg in a Week 13 game against the [[Arizona Cardinals]]. Harvin was also voted the Offensive Rookie of the Year and was named as the NFC's starting kick returner for the [[2010 Pro Bowl]] on January 31, 2010. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ Minnesota Vikings 2009 NFL Draft selections |- ! colspan="3" | Draft order ! rowspan="2" | Player name ! rowspan="2" | Position ! rowspan="2" | Height ! rowspan="2" | Weight ! rowspan="2" | College ! rowspan="2" | Contract ! rowspan="2" | Notes |- ! ''Cowboys 35â31.'' |stats= ;Passing *DAL â [[Rudy Carpenter]] â 12/18, 125 yards, TD *MIN â [[Sage Rosenfels]] â 7/15, 115 yards ;Rushing *DAL â [[Julius Crosslin]] â 9 rushes, 42 yards *MIN â [[Ian Johnson (American football)|Ian Johnson]] â 17 rushes, 61 yards, 2 TD ;Receiving *DAL â [[John Phillips (American football)|John Phillips]] â 3 rec, 75 yards *MIN â [[Bobby Williams (wide receiver)|Bobby Williams]] â 2 rec, 53 yards }} ==Regular season== As well as playing their [[NFC North]] rivals both at home and on the road, the Vikings were scheduled to face opponents from the [[AFC North]] and the [[NFC West]]. They were also handed fixtures against the [[Carolina Panthers]] from the [[NFC South]] and the [[New York Giants]] from the [[NFC East]] by virtue of having won their division in [[2008 Minnesota Vikings season|2008]].{{cite news |title=Vikings: Strong start on the road could set tone |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80fb3c9c&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true |work=NFL.com |publisher=National Football League |date=April 14, 2009 |accessdate=January 26, 2010 }} Based on their opponents' results in 2008, the Vikings had the second-easiest schedule in the league in 2009, with their opponents having won 42.0% of their games in 2008.{{cite web |title=2009 NFL strength of schedule |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/draft09/news/story?id=4027503 |work=ESPN.com |publisher=ESPN |date=June 24, 2009 |accessdate=January 26, 2010 }} ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week ! rowspan="2" | Date ! rowspan="2" | Kickoff ([[Central time zone|CT]]) ! rowspan="2" | Opponent ! colspan="2" | Results ! rowspan="2" | Venue ! rowspan="2" | TV ! rowspan="2" | NFL Recap |- ! '''Drive: 9 plays, 80 yards, 2:35.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 14/21, 110 yards, TD *CLE â [[Brady Quinn]] â 21/35, 205 yards, TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 25 rushes, 180 yards, 3 TD *CLE â [[Jamal Lewis]] â 11 rushes, 57 yards ;Receiving *MIN â [[Percy Harvin]] â 3 rec, 36 yards, TD *CLE â [[Robert Royal]] â 4 rec, 60 yards, TD }} The Vikings began their season at [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] for a Week 1 interconference duel with the [[Cleveland Browns]]. In the first quarter, Minnesota trailed as Browns kicker [[Phil Dawson]] got a 37-yard field goal. The Vikings answered with kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] making a 21-yard field goal. In the second quarter, Minnesota took the lead as running back [[Adrian Peterson]] got a 1-yard touchdown run. Cleveland retook their lead as Dawson kicked a 20-yard field goal, along with wide receiver [[Joshua Cribbs]] returning a punt 67 yards for a touchdown. In the third quarter, the Vikings took control as Peterson got a 1-yard touchdown run, along with quarterback [[Brett Favre]] completing a 6-yard touchdown pass to rookie wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]]. Afterwards, Minnesota put the game out of reach in the fourth quarter; Ryan Longwell nailed a 37-yard field goal, while Adrian Peterson got a 64-yard touchdown run. The Browns closed out the game with quarterback [[Brady Quinn]] completing a 26-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Robert Royal]]. With the win, the Vikings began their season at 1â0. ====Week 2: at Detroit Lions==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 2: Minnesota Vikings at Detroit Lions â Game summary |date=September 20 |time=12:00 p.m. |road='''Vikings''' |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=10 |R4=10 |home=Lions |H1=3 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=3 |stadium=[[Ford Field]], [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] |attendance=56,269 |weather=None (domed stadium) |referee=[[Carl Cheffers]] (51) |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Ron Pitts]] & [[John Lynch (American football)|John Lynch]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009092001/2009/REG2/vikings@lions Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54484/DET_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *DET â [[Jason Hanson]] 30-yard field goal, 5:05. Minnesota trailed early as Lions kicker [[Jason Hanson]] got a 30-yard field goal. Detroit added to their lead in the second quarter as quarterback [[Matthew Stafford]] completed an 8-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Calvin Johnson (American football)|Calvin Johnson]]. The Vikings ended the half with a 1-yard touchdown pass from quarterback [[Brett Favre]] to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]]. In the third quarter, Minnesota took the lead as kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] made a 46-yard field goal, followed by running back [[Adrian Peterson]] getting a 27-yard touchdown run. The Vikings pulled away as Longwell nailed a 46-yard field goal, followed by Favre completing a 3-yard touchdown pass to rookie wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]]. The Lions completed the scoring as Hanson got a 48-yard field goal. With the win, the Vikings improved to 2â0. ====Week 3: vs. San Francisco 49ers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 3: San Francisco 49ers at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=September 27 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=49ers |R1=0 |R2=14 |R3=3 |R4=7 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=7 |H2=6 |H3=7 |H4=7 |stadium=[[Hubert H. '''Drive: 10 plays, 80 yards, 1:27.''''' |stats= ;Passing *SF â [[Shaun Hill]] â 15/25, 195 yards, 2 TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 24/46, 301 yards, 2 TD ;Rushing *SF â [[Glen Coffee]] â 25 rushes, 54 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 19 rushes, 85 yards ;Receiving *SF â [[Vernon Davis]] â 7 rec, 96 yards, 2 TD *MIN â [[Chester Taylor]] â 7 rec, 70 yards }} Coming off their divisional road win over the Lions, the Vikings played their Week 3 home opener against the [[San Francisco 49ers]]. Minnesota opened in the first quarter with quarterback [[Brett Favre]]'s 30-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Sidney Rice]]. The Vikings added onto their lead in the second quarter with kicker [[Ryan Longwell]]'s 40-yard field goal, but the 49ers answered with quarterback [[Shaun Hill]]'s 5-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Vernon Davis]]. Minnesota came back with Longwell's 52-yard field goal, but San Francisco took the lead prior to halftime as cornerback [[Nate Clements]] returned a blocked field goal 59 yards for a touchdown. The 49ers increased their lead in the second half with kicker [[Joe Nedney]]'s 37-yard field goal, but the Vikings immediately responded with rookie wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]] returning a kickoff 101 yards for a touchdown. In the fourth quarter, San Francisco got the lead again with Hill hooking up with Davis on a 20-yard touchdown pass. Afterwards, Minnesota came up with a dramatic win as Favre completed a game-winning 32-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Greg Lewis (wide receiver)|Greg Lewis]] with 2 seconds remaining in the game. The pass was later awarded an [[ESPY Awards|ESPY]] for "Best Play". The game was also voted as the best game of the regular season by voters on NFL.com. With the win, the Vikings improved to 3â0. ====Week 4: vs. Green Bay Packers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 4: Green Bay Packers at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=October 5 |time=7:30 p.m. |road=Packers |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=9 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=7 |H2=14 |H3=7 |H4=2 |stadium=[[Hubert H. '''Drive: 9 plays, 68 yards, 2:15.''''' |stats= ;Passing *GB â [[Aaron Rodgers]] â 26/37, 384 yards, 2 TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 24/31, 271 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *GB â [[Ryan Grant]] â 11 rushes, 51 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 25 rushes, 55 yards, TD ;Receiving *GB â [[Jermichael Finley]] â 6 rec, 128 yards, TD *MIN â [[Bernard Berrian]] â 6 rec, 75 yards, TD }} [[File:2009VikingsPackers.JPG|thumb|Minnesota Vikings versus Green Bay Packers in Week 4 of the 2009 NFL season.]] Coming off their last-second win over the 49ers, the Vikings stayed at home, donned their throwback uniforms, and prepared for the highly anticipated Week 4 NFC North Monday Night Football duel with the [[Green Bay Packers]]. This was a key divisional match-up, as the division lead was on the line, while quarterback [[Brett Favre]] was pitted against his former team. Favre entered the stadium to a series of boos coming from Green Bay fans throughout the stadium, but were drowned out by the cheers from Vikings fans. Minnesota started off the first quarter with Favre completing a 1-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]]. The Packers responded with quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] completing a 62-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Jermichael Finley]]. In the second quarter, the Vikings struck again with a 14-yard touchdown pass from Favre to wide receiver [[Sidney Rice]], but Green Bay answered with linebacker [[Clay Matthews III|Clay Matthews]] stripping running back [[Adrian Peterson]] of the ball and returning it 42 yards for a touchdown. The Vikings closed out the half with a 1-yard touchdown run from Peterson. Minnesota began to build a lead in the third quarter as Favre hooked up with wide receiver [[Bernard Berrian]] on a 31-yard touchdown pass. In the fourth quarter, the Vikings solidified their lead as defensive end [[Jared Allen]] sacked Rodgers in the Green Bay endzone for a safety. The Packers rallied with a 33-yard touchdown pass from Rodgers to wide receiver [[Jordy Nelson]] (with a failed 2-point conversion), followed by kicker [[Mason Crosby]] nailing a 31-yard field goal. However, the Packers' push came too late and Minnesota was able to run out the clock for the win. With the victory, not only did the Vikings improve to 4â0, but Favre became the first quarterback in NFL history to defeat all 32 NFL teams. Allen had a spectacular single-game performance with a career-best 4.5 sacks. Favre was awarded the NFC Offensive Player of the Week, marking the 14th time in his career he has earned this award. ====Week 5: at St. Louis Rams==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 5: Minnesota Vikings at St. Louis Rams â Game summary |date=October 11 |time=12:00 p.m. |road='''Vikings''' |R1=14 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=14 |home=Rams |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=7 |stadium=[[Edward Jones Dome]], [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]] |attendance=60,166 |weather=None (domed stadium) |referee=[[Don Carey (official)|Don Carey]] (126) |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Chris Myers]] & [[Charles Davis (defensive back)|Charles Davis]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009101107/2009/REG5/vikings@rams Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54536/SL_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] 5-yard run ([[Ryan Longwell]] kick), 10:17. '''Drive: 9 plays, 80 yards, 4:50.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 18/24, 232 yards, TD *STL â [[Kyle Boller]] â 20/31, 209 yards ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 14 rushes, 63 yards, 2 TD *STL â [[Steven Jackson]] â 21 rushes, 84 yards ;Receiving *MIN â [[Percy Harvin]] â 4 rec, 66 yards *STL â [[Donnie Avery]] â 5 rec, 87 yards, TD }} Coming off an impressive divisional home win over the Packers, the Vikings flew to the [[Edward Jones Dome]] for a Week 5 duel with the [[St. Louis Rams]]. Minnesota got off to a fast start in the first quarter as running back [[Adrian Peterson]] got a 5-yard touchdown run, followed by defensive end [[Jared Allen]]'s 52-yard fumble return for a touchdown. The Rams got on the board with kicker [[Josh Brown (American football)|Josh Brown]] making a 29-yard field goal, but the Vikings replied with kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] booting a 47-yard field goal. Minnesota kept its dominating performance going in the third quarter as quarterback [[Brett Favre]] hooked up with tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] on a 13-yard touchdown pass. In the fourth quarter, the Vikings continued to pull away as Peterson got a 7-yard touchdown run. St. Louis tried to rally with a 27-yard touchdown pass from quarterback [[Marc Bulger]] to wide receiver [[Donnie Avery]], but Minnesota closed out the game with a 1-yard touchdown run from running back [[Chester Taylor]]. With the win, not only did the Vikings acquire their first 5â0 start since 2003, but Favre (18/24, 232 yards, 1 TD, 1 INT) earned his first 5â0 start in his career. ====Week 6: vs. Baltimore Ravens==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 6: Baltimore Ravens at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=October 18 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Ravens |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=21 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=14 |H2=0 |H3=6 |H4=13 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 1 play, 33 yards, 0:07.''''' *MIN â Ryan Longwell 31-yard field goal, 1:56. ''Vikings 33â31. '''Drive: 6 plays, 66 yards, 1:41.''''' |stats= ;Passing *BAL â [[Joe Flacco]] â 28/43, 385 yards, 2 TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 21/29, 278 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *BAL â [[Ray Rice]] â 10 rushes, 77 yards, 2 TD *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 22 rushes, 143 yards ;Receiving *BAL â Ray Rice â 10 rec, 117 yards *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 6 rec, 176 yards }} Coming off their easy road win over the Rams, the Vikings went home for a Week 6 inter-conference duel with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Minnesota got off to a fast start in the first quarter with quarterback [[Brett Favre]] completing a 19-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] and a 4-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Bernard Berrian]]. Afterwards, the Ravens got the only points of the second quarter as kicker [[Steven Hauschka]] getting a 29-yard field goal. In the third quarter, the Vikings picked up where they left off with a 40-yard field goal from kicker [[Ryan Longwell]]. Baltimore responded with a 22-yard touchdown run from running back [[Ray Rice]], yet Longwell helped out Minnesota by nailing a 22-yard field goal. Afterwards, an action-packed fourth quarter ensued. Minnesota increased its lead with Favre hooking up with Shiancoe again on a 1-yard touchdown pass, but the Ravens continued to hang around as quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] found wide receiver [[Mark J. Clayton|Mark Clayton]] on a 32-yard touchdown pass. The Vikings replied with Longwell's 29-yard field goal, but Baltimore took lead for the first time in the game as Flacco hooked up with wide receiver [[Derrick Mason]] on a 12-yard touchdown pass and Rice running 33 yards for a touchdown. Minnesota then regained the lead as Longwell booted a 31-yard field goal after a 58-yard pass from quarterback Brett Favre to wide receiver Sidney Rice. The Ravens got a last-minute drive into scoring range, but Hauschka's 44-yard field goal attempt went wide left, preserving the Vikings' perfect season. With the win, the Vikings acquired their first 6â0 start since [[2003 Minnesota Vikings season|2003]] (unfortunately that team did not make the playoffs). Also, dating back to Week 17 of the [[2008 Minnesota Vikings season|2008 season]], Minnesota has won seven-straight regular season games for the first time since [[2000 Minnesota Vikings season|2000]]. ====Week 7: at Pittsburgh Steelers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 7: Minnesota Vikings at Pittsburgh Steelers â Game summary |date=October 25 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Vikings |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=3 |R4=7 |home='''Steelers''' |H1=3 |H2=7 |H3=3 |H4=14 |stadium=[[Heinz Field]], [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]] |weather={{convert|52|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} (Sunny) |attendance=65,597 |referee=[[Ron Winter]] (14) |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Kenny Albert]], [[Daryl Johnston]] & [[Tony Siragusa]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009102504/2009/REG7/vikings@steelers Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54561/PIT_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *PIT â [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] 39-yard field goal, 0:04. ''Steelers 27â17.'' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 33/50, 334 yards *PIT â [[Ben Roethlisberger]] â 14/26, 175 yards, TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 18 rushes, 69 yards, TD *PIT â [[Rashard Mendenhall]] â 10 rushes, 69 yards ;Receiving *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 10 rec, 136 yards *PIT â [[Mike Wallace (American football)|Mike Wallace]] â 3 rec, 72 yards, TD }} Coming off their thrilling home win over the Ravens, the Vikings flew to [[Heinz Field]] for a Week 7 interconference duel with the defending Super Bowl champion [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. Minnesota trailed late in the first quarter as Steelers kicker [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] got a 39-yard field goal, but they took the lead in the second quarter as running back [[Adrian Peterson]] got a 1-yard touchdown. However, Pittsburgh retook the lead as quarterback [[Ben Roethlisberger]] hooked up with wide receiver [[Mike Wallace (American football)|Mike Wallace]] on a 40-yard touchdown pass. Both teams exchanged field goals in the third quarter as Reed nailed a 27-yard field goal, while Vikings kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] booted an 18-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Minnesota began to trail big as Vikings quarterback [[Brett Favre]] was stripped by defensive end [[Brett Keisel]], causing a 77-yard fumble return for a touchdown by linebacker [[LaMarr Woodley]]. The Vikings immediately struck back with rookie wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]]'s 88-yard kickoff return for a touchdown, but the Steelers' defense answered right back with linebacker [[Keyaron Fox]]'s 82-yard interception return for a touchdown. The Vikings could not come back to win. The Steelers ended up winning 27â17. With the loss, Minnesota fell to 6â1. ====Week 8: at Green Bay Packers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 8: Minnesota Vikings at Green Bay Packers â Game summary |date=November 1 |time=3:15 p.m. |road='''Vikings''' |R1=7 |R2=10 |R3=7 |R4=14 |home=Packers |H1=3 |H2=0 |H3=17 |H4=6 |stadium=[[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], [[Wisconsin]] |attendance=71,213 |weather={{convert|48|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} (Mostly cloudy) |referee=[[Tony Corrente]] (99) |TV=Fox |TVAnnouncers=[[Thom Brennaman]], [[Troy Aikman]] & [[Pam Oliver]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009110105/2009/REG8/vikings@packers Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54575/GB_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *GB â [[Mason Crosby]] 37-yard field goal, 5:05. '''Drive: 4 plays, 59 yards, 1:50.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 17/28, 244 yards, 4 TD *GB â [[Aaron Rodgers]] â 26/41, 287 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 25 rushes, 97 yards, TD *GB â Aaron Rodgers â 5 rushes, 52 yards ;Receiving *MIN â [[Percy Harvin]] â 5 rec, 84 yards, TD *GB â [[Greg Jennings]] â 7 rec, 81 yards, TD }} Hoping to rebound from their first loss of the season to the Steelers, the Vikings flew to [[Lambeau Field]] for the highly anticipated Week 8 divisional rematch with the [[Green Bay Packers]], as quarterback [[Brett Favre]] made his return to his former team. In the first quarter, the Packers scored the game's first points as kicker [[Mason Crosby]] made a 37-yard field goal following a miscue by Vikings center John Sullivan (Favre audibled for another play but Sullivan snapped the ball before Favre completed his audible). Minnesota responded with a 1-yard touchdown from running back [[Adrian Peterson]]. In the second quarter, the Vikings added onto their lead as Favre completed a 12-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]], followed by kicker [[Ryan Longwell]] (another former Packer) nailing a 41-yard field goal. Minnesota picked up where they left off in the third quarter as Favre hooked up with rookie wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]] on a 51-yard touchdown pass, yet Green Bay started to rally as Crosby booted a 26-yard field goal, followed by quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] finding tight end [[Spencer Havner]] on a 16-yard and a 5-yard touchdown pass. The Vikings answered in the fourth quarter with Favre connecting with tight end/fullback [[Jeff Dugan]] on a 2-yard touchdown pass. The Packers tried to come back as Rodgers completed a 10-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Greg Jennings]] (with a failed 2-point conversion), but Minnesota pulled away with Favre finding wide receiver [[Bernard Berrian]] on a 16-yard touchdown pass. With their first season-sweep of the Packers in four years, the Vikings went into their bye week at 7â1, and took a commanding two and a half game lead in the NFC North over the second-place Packers. Favre threw at least 4 touchdowns for the 21st time in his career, matching the NFL record held by Dan Marino. This also marks Vikings head coach Brad Childress' first win at Green Bay (he is 3â5 overall against the Packers). ====Week 9: Bye week==== During the Vikings' bye week, both Green Bay and Chicago lost their games (to [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers|Tampa Bay]] 38â28 and [[Arizona Cardinals|Arizona]] 41â21 respectively), allowing the Vikings to gain a three-game lead in the division standings and moving them a step closer to qualification for the playoffs and first round bye. ====Week 10: vs. Detroit Lions==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 10: Detroit Lions at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=November 15 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Lions |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=0 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=3 |H2=7 |H3=7 |H4=10 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 8 plays, 71 yards, 4:11.''''' |stats= ;Passing *DET â [[Matthew Stafford]] â 29/51, 224 yards, TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 20/29, 344 yards, TD ;Rushing *DET â [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]] â 12 rushes, 55 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 18 rushes, 133 yards, 2 TD ;Receiving *DET â [[Calvin Johnson (American football)|Calvin Johnson]] â 8 rec, 84 yards *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 7 rec, 201 yards }} Coming off their bye week, the Vikings were at home and met in an NFC North duel with the Detroit Lions, who hadn't won in the Metrodome since 1997. In the first quarter, the Vikings scored the period's only points as kicker Ryan Longwell nailed a 22-yard field goal. They increased their lead in the second quarter as running back Adrian Peterson scored on a 22-yard TD run. However, Lions kicker Jason Hanson kicked a 38-yard field goal late in the quarter. At the beginning of the second half, a fumble by the Lions on their first play from scrimmage was recovered at their 29 yard line by the Vikings. Peterson ran twice on the ensuing drive, scoring on a 1-yard TD run to make it a 17â3 lead. The Lions responded with a 15-play, 84-yard drive, capped off by an 8-yard TD pass from Lions QB Matthew Stafford to TE Will Heller. Nevertheless, the Vikings pulled away in the fourth quarter as Favre completed an 8-yard pass to TE Jeff Dugan and kicker Ryan Longwell nailed a 35-yard field goal. With the win, the Vikings moved to 8â1, and compiled a 4â0 record against their NFC North rivals. The Vikings accrued nearly 500 yards of total offense, including 303 yards in the first half alone. The Vikings also had 13 penalties, a season-high. Wide receiver Sidney Rice had a big day, catching seven passes for 201 yards, including a 56-yard reception in the opening seconds of the fourth quarter. Rice was named NFC Offensive Player of the Week for Week 10, the first time he has received this award. Favre and Peterson were voted Fedex Air and Ground Players of the Week. ====Week 11: vs. Seattle Seahawks==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 11: Seattle Seahawks at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=November 22 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Seahawks |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=3 |R4=6 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=0 |H2=21 |H3=7 |H4=7 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 6 plays, 78 yards, 2:16.''''' |stats= ;Passing *SEA â [[Matt Hasselbeck]] â 19/26, 231 yards *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 22/25, 213 yards, 4 TD ;Rushing *SEA â [[Justin Forsett]] â 8 rushes, 9 yards, TD *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 24 rushes, 82 yards ;Receiving *SEA â [[Nate Burleson]] â 6 rec, 100 yards *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 6 rec, 89 yards, 2 TD }} Coming off their penalty-plagued blowout win over the Lions, the Vikings stayed at home and met in a Week 11 duel with the Seattle Seahawks. After a scoreless first quarter, the Vikings got on the board with QB Brett Favre completing a 23-yard TD pass to wide receiver Percy Harvin. Later in the same quarter, the Vikings increased their lead with an 8-yard TD pass from Favre to tight end Visanthe Shiancoe. Closing out the first half was a 3-yard TD pass from Favre to wide receiver Bernard Berrian to make a 21â0 Vikings halftime lead, the first time of the season the Vikings kept their opponent scoreless in the first half. In the third quarter, the Vikings continued to dominate as Favre found wide receiver Sidney Rice on a 7-yard TD pass. Seattle scored their first points of the game when kicker Olindo Mare nailed a 40-yard field goal. Finally, the Vikings put the game away as second-string QB [[Tarvaris Jackson]] found Rice again on a 34-yard TD pass. The Seahawks tried to rally with a 1-yard TD run by running back Justin Forsett (with a failed 2-point conversion), but the Vikings prevented the Seahawks comeback from advancing any further. With the win, the Vikings improved to 9â1. Brett Favre threw 4 TD passes for the 22nd time in his career (second of the season), breaking the mark set by Dan Marino. ====Week 12: vs. Chicago Bears==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 12: Chicago Bears at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=November 29 |time=3:15 p.m. |road=Bears |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=3 |R4=0 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=0 |H2=24 |H3=3 |H4=9 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 8 plays, 68 yards, 5:09.''''' |stats= ;Passing *CHI â [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] â 18/23, 147 yards, TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 32/48, 392 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *CHI â [[Matt FortÃ©]] â 8 rushes, 27 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 25 rushes, 85 yards, TD ;Receiving *CHI â [[Greg Olsen (American football)|Greg Olsen]] â 7 rec, 45 yards *MIN â [[Percy Harvin]] â 6 rec, 101 yards, TD }} Coming off their easy win over the Seahawks, the Vikings stayed at home, donned their throwback uniforms, and faced the Chicago Bears in a Week 12 duel. After a scoreless first quarter, the Vikings drew first blood as quarterback Brett Favre completed a 15-yard [[Touchdown|TD]] pass to rookie wide receiver Percy Harvin. The Bears responded with QB Jay Cutler firing a 24-yard TD pass to WR Johnny Knox. The Vikings responded with Favre hooking up with running back Chester Taylor on a 10-yard TD pass, along with kicker Ryan Longwell nailing a 52-yard field goal. Finally, the Vikings closed out the first half with Favre finding tight end Visanthe Shiancoe on a 6-yard TD pass. In the third quarter, the Bears tried to rally with kicker Robbie Gould nailing a 38-yard field goal. However, the Vikings finally shut out the Bears for the rest of the second half, and kicker Ryan Longwell made field goals of 37 and 20 yards. Running back Adrian Peterson also had a 5-yard TD run (with a missed extra point attempt). With the win, the Vikings improved to 10â1, and compiled a 5â0 record against their NFC North rivals. Their "magic number" decreased to two, meaning that any combination of two Vikings wins or Packers losses would result in the Vikings clinching their second consecutive NFC North division title. On Wednesday December 2, the NFL honored Brett Favre with the NFC Offensive Player of the Month for November. It was the sixth time in his career that he won the award. ====Week 13: at Arizona Cardinals==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 13: Minnesota Vikings at Arizona Cardinals â Game summary |date=December 6 |time=7:20 p.m. |road=Vikings |R1=7 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=7 |home='''Cardinals''' |H1=7 |H2=14 |H3=6 |H4=3 |stadium=[[University of Phoenix Stadium]], [[Glendale, Arizona|Glendale]], [[Arizona]] |attendance=64,121 |weather=None (dome closed) |referee=[[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] (132) |TV=[[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Al Michaels]], [[Cris Collinsworth]] & [[Andrea Kremer]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009120610/2009/REG13/vikings@cardinals Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54654/ARZ_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *MIN â [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] 3-yard pass from [[Brett Favre]] ([[Ryan Longwell]] kick), 9:47. '''Drive: 9 plays, 84 yards, 2:58.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 30/45, 275 yards, 2 TD *ARI â [[Kurt Warner]] â 22/32, 285 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Percy Harvin]] â 2 rushes, 22 yards *ARI â [[Tim Hightower]] â 6 rushes, 50 yards ;Receiving *MIN â Percy Harvin â 6 rec, 79 yards, TD *ARI â [[Larry Fitzgerald]] â 8 rec, 143 yards, TD }} Coming off their easy home win over the Bears, the Vikings flew to the desert for a Week 13 Sunday Night duel with the defending NFC champion Arizona Cardinals. In the first quarter, Minnesota got on the board with quarterback Brett Favre completing a 3-yard TD pass to tight end Visanthe Shiancoe. It was originally ruled an incomplete pass as Shiancoe stepped out of bounds, but Minnesota challenged and won based on the fact that Shiancoe had both feet in bounds and the referee counted Shiancoe's third step, thereby making the original ruling on the field to be overturned. The Cardinals then responded with quarterback Kurt Warner finding wide receiver Anquan Boldin on a 2-yard TD pass. In the second quarter, Arizona took the lead with Warner finding Boldin again on a 39-yard TD pass. The Vikings responded with kicker Ryan Longwell nailing a 25-yard field goal. However, the Cardinals took the lead at halftime when Warner completed a 34-yard TD pass to wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald. In the third quarter, Arizona increased their lead when kicker Neil Rackers kicked field goals of 31 and 30 yards. In the fourth quarter, Arizona kicker Neil Rackers nailed a 29-yard field goal. However, the Vikings tried to rally with Favre hooking up with rookie wide receiver Percy Harvin on a 31-yard TD pass. The Vikings tried an onside kick, which they did not recover and Arizona ran out the clock to seal their win. With only their second loss of the season, the Vikings not only fell to 10â2, but they lost starting linebacker E.J. Henderson to a season-ending broken leg. ====Week 14: vs. Cincinnati Bengals==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 14: Cincinnati Bengals at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=December 13 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Bengals |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=3 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=0 |H2=16 |H3=7 |H4=7 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 11 plays, 67 yards, 6:15.''''' |stats= ;Passing *CIN â [[Carson Palmer]] â 15/25, 94 yards, TD *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 17/30, 192 yards, TD ;Rushing *CIN â [[Cedric Benson]] â 16 rushes, 96 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 26 rushes, 97 yards, 2 TD ;Receiving *CIN â [[Chad Ochocinco]] â 3 rec, 27 yards, TD *MIN â [[Bernard Berrian]] â 4 rec, 43 yards }} Hoping to rebound from their devastating Sunday Night loss to the Cardinals, the Vikings went home and met the Cincinnati Bengals in a Week 14 duel. After a scoreless first quarter, Minnesota took first blood as kicker Ryan Longwell nailed a 41-yard field goal. They increased their lead later in the quarter with quarterback Brett Favre finding wide receiver Sidney Rice on a 9-yard TD pass. Cincinnati responded with quarterback Carson Palmer finding wide receiver Chad Ochocinco on a 15-yard TD pass, however the Vikings quickly scored two field goals by kicker Ryan Longwell (from 23 and 44 yards out) to put the Vikings up 16â7 at halftime. In the third quarter, the Vikings scored the period's only points as running back Adrian Peterson got a 1-yard TD run. In the fourth quarter, Cincinnati tried to rally with kicker Shayne Graham nailing a 22-yard field goal, but the Vikings put the game away with running back Adrian Peterson's 3-yard TD run. With the win, the Vikings not only improved to 11â2 on the season, they also secured a playoff berth for the second consecutive season and improved upon the record from the previous season (10â6). Their "magic number" decreased to one, meaning that either a Green Bay loss at Pittsburgh or a Vikings win against Carolina on Sunday night would make Minnesota repeat division champions for the first time since 1978, when they won six consecutive NFC Central titles. Also, if the Eagles lost against San Francisco, the Vikings would also clinch a first-round bye in the NFC playoffs. ====Week 15: at Carolina Panthers==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 15: Minnesota Vikings at Carolina Panthers â Game summary |date=December 20 |time=7:20 p.m. |road=Vikings |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=0 |home='''Panthers''' |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=0 |H4=20 |stadium=[[Bank of America Stadium]], [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]] |attendance=73,515 |weather={{convert|37|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} (Partly cloudy) |referee=[[Pete Morelli]] (135) |TV=NBC |TVAnnouncers=[[Al Michaels]] & [[Cris Collinsworth]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009122012/2009/REG15/vikings@panthers Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54689/CAR_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *''None.'' ;2nd Quarter *CAR â [[Brad Hoover]] 1-yard pass from [[Matt Moore (American football)|Matt Moore]] (kick blocked), 10:55. '''Drive: 8 plays, 80 yards, 5:01.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 17/27, 224 yards *CAR â [[Matt Moore (American football)|Matt Moore]] â 21/33, 299 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 12 rushes, 35 yards, TD *CAR â [[Jonathan Stewart]] â 25 rushes, 109 yards, TD ;Receiving *MIN â Adrian Peterson â 3 rec, 73 yards *CAR â [[Steve Smith (American football, born 1979)|Steve Smith]] â 9 rec, 157 yards, TD }} Coming off their home win over the Bengals, the Vikings flew to Bank of America Stadium to face the Carolina Panthers in a Week 15 Sunday Night duel. The Vikings clinched the NFC North about an hour before the game thanks in part to Pittsburgh's 37â36 last-second win over the Packers. With a win, the Vikings would be one game behind New Orleans to clinch homefield advantage. After a scoreless first quarter, Carolina got on the board with quarterback Matt Moore finding fullback Brad Hoover on a 1-yard TD pass. The extra point attempt was blocked, however. The Vikings then took the lead later in the quarter with running back Adrian Peterson's 4-yard TD run. After yet another scoreless quarter, it was all Carolina as Matt Moore completed a 42-yard TD pass to wide receiver Steve Smith, as well as running back Jonathan Stewart running in a 3-yard TD, as well as catching a 2-yard TD pass from Moore. With the loss, the Vikings fell to 11â3. Reports surfaced after the game suggesting that there was tension between Vikings quarterback Brett Favre and head coach Brad Childress. The incident was later resolved. ====Week 16: at Chicago Bears==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 16: Minnesota Vikings at Chicago Bears â Game summary |date=December 28 |time=7:30 p.m. |road=Vikings |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=13 |R4=17 |R5=0 |home='''Bears''' |H1=3 |H2=13 |H3=7 |H4=7 |H5=6 |stadium=[[Soldier Field]], [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] |attendance=62,479 |weather={{convert|26|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} (Partly cloudy) |referee=[[Gene Steratore]] (114) |TV=ESPN |TVAnnouncers=[[Mike Tirico]], [[Ron Jaworski]] & [[Jon Gruden]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2009122800/2009/REG16/vikings@bears Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54706/CHI_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *CHI â [[Robbie Gould]] 22-yard field goal, 7:24. '''Drive: 1 play, 39 yards, 0:06.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 26/40, 321 yards, 2 TD *CHI â [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] â 20/35, 273 yards, 4 TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 24 rushes, 94 yards, 2 TD *CHI â [[Matt FortÃ©]] â 21 rushes, 74 yards ;Receiving *MIN â [[Bernard Berrian]] â 3 rec, 58 yards *CHI â [[Devin Aromashodu]] â 7 rec, 150 yards, TD }} Hoping to rebound from their fourth-quarter collapse to the Panthers, the Vikings flew to Soldier Field to face Jay Cutler and the Chicago Bears in a Week 16 rematch to conclude the 40th season of Monday Night Football. Due to the Saints losing to Tampa Bay 20â17 in overtime the previous day, the Vikings needed to win their last two games and have the Saints lose to Carolina the next week in order to clinch homefield advantage. In the first quarter, the Bears drew first blood as kicker Robbie Gould nailed a 22-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, the Bears increased their lead with Gould nailing a 42-yard field goal. They increased their lead with Cutler firing a 7-yard TD pass to tight end Greg Olsen. The Bears then closed out the first half with Gould's 41-yard field goal. In the third quarter, the Vikes started to rally with running back Adrian Peterson's 1-yard touchdown run (with the extra point attempt blocked). The Bears increased their lead over the Vikings with Cutler's 2-yard TD pass to tight end Desmond Clark. The Vikings then closed out the quarter with quarterback Brett Favre firing a 6-yard TD pass to tight end Visanthe Shiancoe. An exciting fourth quarter ensued. The Vikings started out the quarter's scoring with kicker Ryan Longwell's 41-yard field goal, along with Adrian Peterson's second 1-yard TD run. The Bears then responded with Cutler firing a 20-yard TD pass to wide receiver Earl Bennett. The Vikings then completed the remarkable comeback with Favre finding wide receiver Sidney Rice on a 6-yard TD pass on 4th-and-goal with 15 seconds left in regulation. The Bears then took a knee to force overtime. In overtime, the Bears won the toss and marched down the field, stopping at the 35-yard line. However, the potential game-winning 45-yard field goal attempt by Gould went wide right, giving the Vikings a chance to win. After a exchange of punts, the Vikings had the ball at the 26-yard line with 11 minutes left in the period. On the first play of scrimmage, Favre fired a screen pass to Peterson who caught it and went 16 yards, before being confronted by Hunter Hillenmeyer, who caused Peterson to fumble the ball, which was then recovered by Bears' linebacker Nick Roach. The Bears then won on Jay Cutler's game-winning 39-yard TD pass to wide receiver Devin Aromashodu. With the loss, not only did the Vikings fall to 11â4, they also surrendered homefield advantage to the Saints. ====Week 17: vs. New York Giants==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=Week 17: New York Giants at Minnesota Vikings â Game summary |date=January 3 |time=12:00 p.m. |road=Giants |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |home='''Vikings''' |H1=7 |H2=24 |H3=13 |H4=0 |stadium=Mall of America Field at Hubert H. '''Drive: 11 plays, 77 yards, 5:59.''''' |stats= ;Passing *NYG â [[Eli Manning]] â 17/23, 141 yards *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 25/31, 316 yards, 4 TD ;Rushing *NYG â [[DJ Ware]] â 5 rushes, 22 yards, TD *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 9 rushes, 54 yards, TD ;Receiving *NYG â [[Steve Smith (American football, born 1985)|Steve Smith]] â 10 rec, 57 yards *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 6 rec, 112 yards, 2 TD }} Hoping to break a two-game primetime losing skid, the Vikings went home to Mall of America Field for the Week 17 season finale against the New York Giants. The Vikings needed a win '''and''' an Eagles loss to Dallas later in the day in order to clinch a first-round bye in the playoffs. They also came into the game hoping to go 8â0 at home for the first time since the 15â1 season of 1998. The Vikings drew first blood in the first quarter with quarterback Brett Favre finding tight end Visanthe Shiancoe (a former Giant) on a 10-yard TD pass for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, the Vikings increased their lead with kicker Ryan Longwell's 41-yard field goal. Later in the quarter, it was all touchdowns as Adrian Peterson scored from one yard out, as well as Favre firing two touchdown passes to wide receiver Sidney Rice from 4 and 12 yards out. The 31â0 halftime lead was the second time of the season that the Vikes shut out their opponent in the first half, as well as tying a franchise record for the largest halftime lead. In the third quarter, the Vikings continued to destroy the Giants with Favre's 1-yard TD pass to fullback Naufahu Tahi on 4th-and-goal, along with kicker Ryan Longwell's field goals of 24 and 27 yards. The Giants only mustered a 1-yard TD run in the fourth quarter by running back Danny Ware. With the win, the Vikings improved to 12â4, the franchise's best record since the 15â1 1998 campaign. With Dallas beating Philadelphia 24â0 later in the day, the Vikings clinched a first-round bye. Brett Favre threw at least four TD passes for the third time this season, as well as being honored with his third NFC Offensive Player of the Week award. The three awards are the most he has received in one season in his 19-year NFL career. ==Postseason== ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! rowspan="2" | Week !! rowspan="2" | Date !! rowspan="2" | Kickoff ([[North American Central Time Zone|CT]]) !! rowspan="2" | Opponent !! colspan="2" | Results !! rowspan="2" | Game site !! rowspan="2" | TV !! rowspan="2" | NFL.com

'''Drive: 6 plays, 37 yards, 3:31.''''' |stats= ;Passing *DAL â [[Tony Romo]] â 22/35, 198 yards *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 15/24, 234 yards, 4 TD ;Rushing *DAL â [[Felix Jones]] â 14 rushes, 69 yards *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 26 rushes, 63 yards ;Receiving *DAL â [[Jason Witten]] â 10 rec, 98 yards *MIN â [[Sidney Rice]] â 6 rec, 141 yards, 3 TD }} This game began while many TV show hosts and sports analysts were convinced that a red-hot Dallas team was going to end the Vikings' explosive season with Brett Favre. Romo had been throwing more accurately than ever, and because the Vikings had a week off, even their own fans were feeling the pressure of facing a tough Dallas team. Entering the playoffs as the NFC's #2 seed, the Vikings began their playoff run at home in the NFC Divisional Round against the #3 [[Dallas Cowboys]]. Minnesota delivered the opening strike in the first quarter as quarterback [[Brett Favre]] found wide receiver [[Sidney Rice]] on a 47-yard touchdown pass. The Cowboys got on the board in the second quarter with a 33-yard field goal from kicker [[Shaun Suisham]], yet the Vikings came right back with Favre hooking up with Rice again on a 16-yard touchdown pass, followed by a 23-yard field goal from kicker [[Ryan Longwell]]. After a scoreless third quarter, Minnesota delivered the final strike in the fourth quarter as Longwell nailed a 28-yard field goal, followed by Favre's 45-yard touchdown pass to Rice and his 11-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]]. With the win, the Vikings advanced to their ninth [[NFC Championship Game]] in team history, and their first appearance since the 2000 season (lost 41â0 to the New York Giants) with a 13â4 record. Brett Favre became the oldest player to start and win a playoff game, but also won his first postseason game in four against Dallas. ====NFC Championship Game: at New Orleans Saints==== {{Americanfootballbox |titlestyle={{NFLPrimaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};{{NFLSecondaryColor|Minnesota Vikings}};text-align:center |state=autocollapse |title=NFC Championship: Minnesota Vikings at New Orleans Saints â Game summary |date=January 24 |time=5:40 p.m. |road=Vikings |R1=14 |R2=0 |R3=7 |R4=7 |R5=0 |home='''Saints''' |H1=7 |H2=7 |H3=7 |H4=7 |H5=3 |stadium=[[Louisiana Superdome]], [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] |attendance=71,276 |weather=None (domed stadium) |referee=[[Pete Morelli]] (135) |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Joe Buck]], [[Troy Aikman]], [[Pam Oliver]] & [[Chris Myers]] |reference=[http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2010012401/2009/POST20/vikings@saints Recap], [http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/54813/NO_Gamebook.pdf Game Book] |scoring= ;1st Quarter *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] 19-yard run ([[Ryan Longwell]] kick), 9:35. '''Drive: 9 plays, 80 yards, 5:21.''''' ;4th Quarter *NO â [[Reggie Bush]] 5-yard pass from Drew Brees (Garrett Hartley kick), 12:39. ''Saints 28â21. '''Drive: 3 plays, 7 yards, 1:31.''''' *MIN â Adrian Peterson 2-yard run (Ryan Longwell kick), 4:58. ''Tied 28â28. '''Drive: 7 plays, 57 yards, 2:59.''''' ;Overtime *NO â Garrett Hartley 40-yard field goal, 10:15. ''Saints 31â28. '''Drive: 10 plays, 39 yards, 4:45.''''' |stats= ;Passing *MIN â [[Brett Favre]] â 28/46, 310 yards, TD *NO â [[Drew Brees]] â 17/31, 197 yards, 3 TD ;Rushing *MIN â [[Adrian Peterson]] â 25 rushes, 122 yards, 3 TD *NO â [[Pierre Thomas (American football)|Pierre Thomas]] â 14 rushes, 61 yards, TD ;Receiving *MIN â [[Bernard Berrian]] â 9 rec, 102 yards *NO â [[Devery Henderson]] â 4 rec, 39 yards, TD }} Coming off their dominant divisional home win over the Cowboys, the Vikings flew to the [[Louisiana Superdome]] for the [[NFC Championship Game]] against the top-seeded [[New Orleans Saints]]. Minnesota delivered the opening strike in the first quarter with running back [[Adrian Peterson]]'s 19-yard touchdown run. The Saints answered with quarterback [[Drew Brees]] completing a 38-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Pierre Thomas (American football)|Pierre Thomas]], yet the Vikings regained the lead as quarterback [[Brett Favre]] found wide receiver [[Sidney Rice]] on a 5-yard touchdown pass. In the second quarter, New Orleans tied the game again on Brees' 9-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Devery Henderson]]. The Saints took the lead in the third quarter with Thomas' 9-yard touchdown run, yet Minnesota tied the game as Peterson got a 1-yard touchdown run. In the fourth quarter, New Orleans got the lead again as Brees hooked up with running back [[Reggie Bush]] on a 5-yard touchdown pass, yet the Vikings tied the game again with Peterson's 2-yard touchdown run. After stopping the Saints offense the Vikings got the ball back and were close to field goal range in the final 30 seconds when they were flagged for too many men on the field; on the next play Favre rolled to the right as a hole opened up, but instead of running forward he threw the ball deep across his body and it was picked off by the Saints, forcing overtime. In overtime, New Orleans drove down field amid a number of controversial calls,{{cn|date=June 2011}} and Minnesota fell as Saints kicker [[Garrett Hartley]] nailed the game-ending 40-yard field goal. With the loss, the Vikings' season ended with an overall record of 13â5. Doomed by turnovers â the Vikings had an uncanny six fumbles, three of which they lost, plus two interceptions by Brett Favre â the Vikes lost another NFC Championship Game in overtime, this one reminiscent of the 1998â99 loss to the [[Atlanta Falcons]] in the Metrodome. ==Pro Bowl== Eight Minnesota Vikings players were originally selected for the [[2010 Pro Bowl]]: five on offense (Brett Favre, Adrian Peterson, Sidney Rice, Bryant McKinnie and Steve Hutchinson), two on defense (Jared Allen and Kevin Williams) and one special teamer (Heath Farwell). Of these, six were selected to start the game, with Favre and Rice going as reserves.{{cite news |title=2010 Pro Bowl rosters |url=http://www.nfl.com/probowl/story?id=09000d5d8155c2fa&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true |work=NFL.com |publisher=National Football League |date=December 30, 2009 |accessdate=December 30, 2009 }} However, as [[Philadelphia Eagles]] wide receiver [[DeSean Jackson]] was voted as a starter at both wide receiver and kickoff returner, a replacement had to be selected at KR; Percy Harvin was added to the roster on January 4, 2010, making it nine Vikings in the NFC roster.{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Wobschall |title=Harvin Added To Pro Bowl Roster |url=http://blog.vikings.com/2010/01/04/harvin-added-to-pro-bowl-roster/ |work=vikings.com |publisher=Minnesota Vikings Football |date=January 4, 2010 |accessdate=January 5, 2010 }} [[Antoine Winfield]] was added to the NFC roster as an extra [[cornerback]] on January 19, 2010, bringing the Vikings' contribution to the roster to 10 players.{{cite news |title=Vikings CB Winfield receives second consecutive Pro Bowl honor |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d815d4f6a&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true |work=nfl.com |publisher=National Football League |date=January 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 19, 2010 }} Had the Vikings reached [[Super Bowl XLIV]], none of their players would have appeared in the 2010 Pro Bowl, but they lost to the [[New Orleans Saints]] in the NFC Championship Game. Nevertheless, QB Brett Favre (ankle), CB Antoine Winfield (foot) and KR Percy Harvin (migraine headaches) all pulled out as a result of their various ailments.{{cite news |title=Pro Bowl rosters receiver makeover with 17 new players |url=http://www.nfl.com/probowl/story?id=09000d5d815f832a&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true |work=NFL.com |publisher=National Football League |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=January 26, 2010 }} OT Bryant McKinnie was cut from the NFC roster on January 30 after missing four of the five practice sessions and attending only one team meeting; he claimed, via [[SMS|text message]] to the [[Star Tribune]], that his absence was due to a lack of physical fitness. McKinnie was not replaced in the roster and was also fined his game check.{{cite news |title=Vikings OT McKinnie off NFC Pro Bowl team after missing practices |url=http://www.nfl.com/probowl/story?id=09000d5d8161494d&template=with-video-with-comments&confirm=true |work=NFL.com |publisher=National Football League |date=January 30, 2010 |accessdate=February
